Locus.desc: The physical result of any single action whether it leaves a positive or negative record within the stratigraphic sequence. (MoLAS 1994)

Locus_ID.desc: Every archaeological locus (negative element (cut), deposit, structure, skeleton, artefact cluster) is given a unique 3 or 4 letter locus code. Each trench is designated with a separate letter which starts the code, so it is immediately obvious to which trench a locus belongs. For example locus HAA belongs to Trench H, locus MQP to Trench M etc. The loci are labelled consecutively in alphabetical order using the letters following the trench letter. For Trench H the first locus would be HAA, the second HAB, the third HAB and so on. In addition sets of letters can denote parts of trenches, buildings etc. E.g. HFs might denote loci from a specific building. Burial locus codes begin with the letter Z, followed by the trench letter. Hence burial ZHA is the first burial locus from trench H. Check with the trench supervisor who will assign the locus code from the central register.

Basal_Edge_Definition.desc: Describe the boundary between this and the next locus.

opts.opt: DoubtfulYou are uncertain of whether you accurately excavated a boundary between deposits
AmbiguousYou are uncertain as to whether there was a boundary between loci.
MergingThere is a distinction between the excavated locus and earlier locus/loci but the excavated loci and the earlier loci grade into each other
ClearThe boundary with the earlier locus/loci was very clearly defined during excavation.
Arbitrary SpitThere is no meaningful boundary with an earlier locus. The boundary has been artificially created by the excavation process.

Contamination.desc: The extent to which the locus has been contaminated.

Locus_Type.desc: Describe the locus type by selecting an icon as defined below. When you have selected a locus type you can proceed to open the "Fill in locus type details" page. Note this page will not open unless you have selected a locus type.

opts.opt: Pit Any Locus which represents the removal of earlier deposit and thus forms a negative interface (cut) with another locus, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
Fill Any Locus with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
Surface Any Locus with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
Architecture Any Locus consisting of deliberately constructed structural element, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as a wall or a hearth).

Skeleton.Skeleton_Dimensions: Dimensions Record the approximate extent of the skeletal remains (in meters or millimetres only) and the axis of measurement. Detailed dimensions can be taken from the plan.

cols.Skeleton_Head: Head Which way up the head faces and/or points
cols.Skeleton_Body: Body Describe the attitude of the body, whether it is extended, crouched, flexed, supine (front up), prone (face down) and the orientation.

cols.Skeleton_Left_Arm: Left Arm and Hand Location Record whether left arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.
cols.Skeleton_Right_Arm: Right Arm and Hand Location Record whether right arm is straight or flexed, is along the side of the body, over the chest or on the pelvis, and the position of the hand.

cols.Skeleton_Left_Leg: Left Leg and Foot Location Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot
cols.Skeleton_Right_Leg: Right Leg and Foot Location Record whether the leg is straight or bent, crossed left over right or right over left and the position of the foot

Skeleton.Skeleton_Condition: Condition Describe the general condition of the skeleton and any comments on articulation. Any degeneration of bone in situ is important to record as well as accidental damage during excavation and lifting. Record disturbances through later activity or animal/root activity as well as damage due to stone pressure on the bones. It is important to note whether the patellae, hyoid, phalanges, basi-occipital etc are present or not, and their location, as this may give an indication of the state of the body at the time of interment.
Skeleton.Skeleton_Surface_Modifications: Surface Modifications Note any cut marks, evidence of stains and/or colour during the course of the excavation, burning, chewing marks, root activity etc.
Skeleton.Skeleton_Environment: Condition and Weather The physical environment at the time of excavation may affect the state of the bone therefore it is important to note the weather and conditions you are working in.
Skeleton.Skeleton_Days_Exposed: Number of Days Exposed It is important to excavate skeletal remains as quickly as possible as the state of the bone will change during exposure. Any conditional change should also be noted. Excavate as quickly as possible because the bones will degrade rapidly.
